metadata.title: We Have Always Lived in the Castle
metadata.author: Shirley Jackson

knowledge_zone.heading: Foreshadowing: Creates meaning in the text

sections.content: Foreshadowing is used throughout the text to creates meaning in the text.

examples.quote: they tell me you're moving away
examples.scene: Jim Donell persistently questioning Merricat about leaving the village
examples.effect: Hints at future disruption to the Blackwood isolation while showing how the village projects their desires onto the family

examples.quote: A change was coming, and nobody knew it but me
examples.scene: Merricat reflects after the tea party visitors leave
examples.effect: Creates ominous anticipation while filtering through Merricat's unreliable perception of what constitutes 'change'

examples.quote: I am going to put death in all their food
examples.scene: Merricat's threat after witnessing the village destruction
examples.effect: Previews the sisters' future isolation and Merricat's unchanged murderous nature, suggesting the cycle of violence will continue

pedagogy_zone.heading: From Device Spotting to Analysis
pedagogy_zone.intro_text: Most students can identify a device. Strong analysis shows what it DOES. Don't just label it—explain its function in creating meaning.

content.question: Ask yourself: Why does the author use Foreshadowing HERE? What meaning does it create in this specific moment?
content.framework: Use TVODE: Technique → Verb → Observation → Device effect → Evaluation

pedagogy_zone.essay_application: In your essays, always connect device to meaning. Show HOW the technique creates the effect, don't just identify that it's there.
